Applied Electricity.name: Ohm's Law
Applied Electricity.description: Describes the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in an electrical circuit, used to calculate one variable when the other two are known, fundamental for analyzing DC circuits.

example.problem: \text{Find the voltage across a } 10 \, \Omega \text{ resistor with a current of } 2 \, \text{A}.

Applied Electricity.name: Electric Power (Basic Form)
Applied Electricity.description: Calculates the rate at which electrical energy is consumed or produced in a circuit, essential for determining power requirements in devices and systems.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the power consumed by a device with } 12 \, \text{V} \text{ and } 5 \, \text{A}.

Applied Electricity.name: Electrical Power (Resistance-Based Form)
Applied Electricity.description: Alternative expressions derived from Ohm's Law to compute power when voltage or current is not directly available, commonly used in heating elements and efficiency calculations.

example.problem: \text{Find the power dissipated in a } 8 \, \Omega \text{ resistor with } 4 \, \text{A} \text{ flowing through it.}

Applied Electricity.name: Electrical Energy

variables.E: Energy (in joules, J, or watt-hours, Wh)
variables.t: Time (in seconds, s, or hours, h)

Applied Electricity.description: Determines the total electrical energy used or generated over time, applied in billing, battery life estimation, and energy consumption analysis.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the energy consumed by a } 100 \, \text{W} \text{ bulb operating for } 2 \, \text{hours}.

Applied Electricity.name: Joule's Law (Heating Effect)
Applied Electricity.description: Quantifies the heat energy produced by current flowing through a resistor, used in designing fuses, heaters, and understanding thermal effects in circuits.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the heat generated by a } 5 \, \Omega \text{ resistor with } 3 \, \text{A} \text{ for } 10 \, \text{s}.

Applied Electricity.name: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (KVL)

variables.V: Individual voltages (in volts, V) including sources and drops

Applied Electricity.description: States that the algebraic sum of all voltages in a closed loop is zero, used to analyze complex circuits by setting up equations for voltage drops and sources.

example.problem: \text{In a loop with a } 12 \, \text{V} \text{ battery and two resistors with voltage drops of } 5 \, \text{V} \text{ and } 7 \, \text{V}, \text{ verify KVL.}

Applied Electricity.name: Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL)

variables.I: Individual currents (in amperes, A) at a junction

Applied Electricity.description: States that the total current entering a node equals the total current leaving, essential for solving current distribution in branched circuits.

example.problem: \text{At a junction, } 10 \, \text{A} \text{ enters, and } 6 \, \text{A} \text{ and } 4 \, \text{A} \text{ leave. Verify KCL.}

Applied Electricity.name: Total Resistance in Series
Applied Electricity.description: Calculates the combined resistance when resistors are connected end-to-end, used to simplify series circuits for analysis.

example.problem: \text{Find the total resistance of three resistors: } 10 \, \Omega, 20 \, \Omega, \text{ and } 30 \, \Omega \text{ in series.}

Applied Electricity.name: Total Resistance in Parallel
Applied Electricity.description: Finds the equivalent resistance for resistors connected side-by-side, applied in designing circuits with multiple paths for current.

example.problem: \text{Find the total resistance of two resistors, } 6 \, \Omega \text{ and } 12 \, \Omega, \text{ in parallel.}

Applied Electricity.name: Capacitance Charge
Applied Electricity.description: Relates the charge stored in a capacitor to its capacitance and applied voltage, used in timing circuits and energy storage applications.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the charge stored in a } 2 \, \mu\text{F} \text{ capacitor with } 10 \, \text{V} \text{ applied.}

Applied Electricity.name: Capacitive Reactance
Applied Electricity.description: Measures a capacitor's opposition to AC current, decreasing with higher frequency, used in AC circuit design and filtering.

example.problem: \text{Find the capacitive reactance of a } 5 \, \mu\text{F} \text{ capacitor at } 50 \, \text{Hz.}

Applied Electricity.name: Inductive Reactance
Applied Electricity.description: Quantifies an inductor's opposition to AC current, increasing with higher frequency, applied in motors, transformers, and AC analysis.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the inductive reactance of a } 0.1 \, \text{H} \text{ inductor at } 60 \, \text{Hz.}

Applied Electricity.name: Impedance in Series RLC Circuit
Applied Electricity.description: Represents the total opposition to AC current in a circuit with resistance, inductance, and capacitance, used for calculating current in AC circuits.

example.problem: \text{Find the impedance of an RLC circuit with } R = 10 \, \Omega, X_L = 20 \, \Omega, \text{ and } X_C = 15 \, \Omega.

Applied Electricity.name: Power Factor
Applied Electricity.description: Indicates the efficiency of power usage in AC circuits by showing the ratio of real to apparent power, used in optimizing industrial loads and reducing energy losses.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the power factor for an AC circuit with } R = 8 \, \Omega \text{ and } Z = 10 \, \Omega.

Applied Electricity.name: Transformer Voltage Ratio
Applied Electricity.description: Describes the voltage transformation in a transformer based on the turn ratio, used for stepping up or down voltages in power distribution.

example.problem: \text{A transformer has } 100 \text{ primary turns and } 500 \text{ secondary turns. If the primary voltage is } 120 \, \text{V}, \text{ find the secondary voltage.}

Applied Electricity.name: Three-Phase Power
Applied Electricity.description: Calculates power in balanced three-phase systems, common in industrial applications for efficient power transmission and motor operation.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the power in a three-phase system with } V_L = 400 \, \text{V}, I_L = 10 \, \text{A}, \text{ and } \cos \phi = 0.9.

Applied Electricity.name: RMS Voltage (for Sinusoidal AC)

variables.V_{\\text{rms}}: Root mean square voltage (in volts, V)

Applied Electricity.description: Converts peak AC voltage to its effective DC equivalent, used for consistent power calculations in AC circuits.

example.problem: \text{Find the RMS voltage of a sinusoidal AC signal with a peak voltage of } 170 \, \text{V}.

Applied Electricity.name: RMS Current (for Sinusoidal AC)

variables.I_{\\text{rms}}: Root mean square current (in amperes, A)

Applied Electricity.description: Converts the peak current of a sinusoidal AC waveform to its effective DC equivalent, used for consistent power calculations and equipment ratings in AC circuits.

example.problem: \text{Find the RMS current for a sinusoidal AC signal with a peak current of } 14.14 \, \text{A}.

Applied Electricity.name: Time Constant for RC Circuit
Applied Electricity.description: Calculates the time required for a capacitor in an RC circuit to charge or discharge to about 63% of its final value, used in timing circuits and filters.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the time constant for an RC circuit with } R = 1000 \, \Omega \text{ and } C = 2 \, \mu\text{F}.

Applied Electricity.name: Time Constant for RL Circuit
Applied Electricity.description: Determines the time taken for the current in an RL circuit to reach about 63% of its final value, applied in inductor-based circuits like motors and relays.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the time constant for an RL circuit with } L = 0.5 \, \text{H} \text{ and } R = 100 \, \Omega.

Applied Electricity.name: Resonant Frequency of an LC Circuit
Applied Electricity.description: Finds the frequency at which an LC circuit naturally oscillates, used in radio tuners, filters, and oscillators.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the resonant frequency of an LC circuit with } L = 0.1 \, \text{H} \text{ and } C = 10 \, \mu\text{F}.

Applied Electricity.name: Apparent Power

variables.V: Voltage (in volts, V, typically RMS in AC)
variables.I: Current (in amperes, A, typically RMS in AC)

Applied Electricity.description: Represents the total power in an AC circuit, combining real and reactive power, used in sizing transformers and generators.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the apparent power in an AC circuit with } V_{\text{rms}} = 230 \, \text{V} \text{ and } I_{\text{rms}} = 5 \, \text{A}.

Applied Electricity.name: Reactive Power
Applied Electricity.description: Measures the power stored and returned in reactive components (capacitors and inductors), used in AC power system analysis and power factor correction.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the reactive power in an AC circuit with } V_{\text{rms}} = 230 \, \text{V}, I_{\text{rms}} = 5 \, \text{A}, \text{ and } \sin \phi = 0.6.

Applied Electricity.name: True Power

variables.V: Voltage (in volts, V, typically RMS in AC)
variables.I: Current (in amperes, A, typically RMS in AC)

Applied Electricity.description: Calculates the actual power consumed or delivered in an AC circuit, accounting for the phase difference between voltage and current.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the true power in an AC circuit with } V_{\text{rms}} = 230 \, \text{V}, I_{\text{rms}} = 5 \, \text{A}, \text{ and } \cos \phi = 0.8.

Applied Electricity.name: Total Capacitance in Series
Applied Electricity.description: Calculates the combined capacitance when capacitors are connected in series, used in circuit design for timing or filtering properties.

example.problem: \text{Find the total capacitance of two capacitors, } 4 \, \mu\text{F} \text{ and } 8 \, \mu\text{F}, \text{ in series.}

Applied Electricity.name: Total Capacitance in Parallel
Applied Electricity.description: Determines the total capacitance for capacitors connected in parallel, applied in increasing charge storage capacity in circuits.

example.problem: \text{Find the total capacitance of two capacitors, } 4 \, \mu\text{F} \text{ and } 8 \, \mu\text{F}, \text{ in parallel.}

Applied Electricity.name: Total Inductance in Series
Applied Electricity.description: Computes the combined inductance for inductors connected in series, used in designing magnetic circuits like transformers.

example.problem: \text{Find the total inductance of two inductors, } 0.2 \, \text{H} \text{ and } 0.3 \, \text{H}, \text{ in series.}

Applied Electricity.name: Total Inductance in Parallel
Applied Electricity.description: Finds the equivalent inductance for inductors in parallel, used in circuits requiring reduced inductance such as filters.

example.problem: \text{Find the total inductance of two inductors, } 0.4 \, \text{H} \text{ and } 0.8 \, \text{H}, \text{ in parallel.}

Applied Electricity.name: Voltage Divider Rule

variables.V_x: Voltage across resistor R_x (in volts, V)
variables.R_x: Resistance of the specific resistor (in Ohms, Ω)
variables.R_{\\text{total}}: Sum of all resistances in series (in Ohms, Ω)

Applied Electricity.description: Calculates the voltage drop across a specific resistor in a series circuit, used for designing circuits with specific voltage outputs.

example.problem: \text{In a series circuit with } V_{\text{source}} = 12 \, \text{V}, R_1 = 3 \, \Omega, \text{ and } R_2 = 5 \, \Omega, \text{ find the voltage across } R_2.

Applied Electricity.name: Current Divider Rule

variables.I_x: Current through a specific branch (in amperes, A)
variables.I_{\\text{total}}: Total current entering the parallel circuit (in amperes, A)
variables.R_x: Resistance of the specific branch (in Ohms, Ω)
variables.R_{\\text{eq}}: Equivalent resistance of the parallel circuit (in Ohms, Ω)

Applied Electricity.description: Determines the current through a specific branch in a parallel circuit, used in analyzing current distribution.

example.problem: \text{In a parallel circuit with } I_{\text{total}} = 12 \, \text{A}, R_1 = 6 \, \Omega, \text{ and } R_2 = 12 \, \Omega, \text{ find the current through } R_2.

Applied Electricity.name: Magnetic Flux

variables.A: Area perpendicular to the field (in square meters, m^2)
variables.\\theta: Angle between field and area normal (in degrees or radians)

Applied Electricity.description: Quantifies the magnetic field passing through a surface, used in designing transformers and motors.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the magnetic flux through a } 0.01 \, \text{m}^2 \text{ loop in a } 0.5 \, \text{T} \text{ field, with } \theta = 0^\circ.

Applied Electricity.name: Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction

variables.\\varepsilon: Induced electromotive force (EMF, in volts, V)
variables.N: Number of turns in the coil

Applied Electricity.description: Relates the rate of change of magnetic flux to induced voltage, fundamental for generators, transformers, and inductors.

example.problem: \text{A } 50 \text{-turn coil experiences a flux change from } 0.02 \, \text{Wb} \text{ to } 0.01 \, \text{Wb} \text{ in } 0.1 \, \text{s. Find the induced EMF.}

Applied Electricity.name: Efficiency of an Electrical System
Applied Electricity.description: Measures how effectively a system converts input power to useful output power, used in evaluating motors, transformers, and power supplies.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the efficiency of a motor with an input power of } 1000 \, \text{W} \text{ and an output power of } 850 \, \text{W}.
